prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Practical Advice for Protecting Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: In order to protect confidential information, a business must ensure that appropriate measures are taken to ensure that the relative secrecy of the information remains intact. As we have seen in previous chapters, information of a confidential nature will normally be protected by the courts where it has not become generally known to others within the industry or trade. Further, within the business entity, information of value should only be provided to those requiring it in order to perform their job duties.[1] Finally, during any negotiations with third parties, information of value should be closely monitored, and it should be provided only after it has been clearly identified as confidential.

The extent to which information is known both inside and outside the business will be a key factor in determining whether it is confidential. Accordingly, a business seeking to protect information must generally ensure that the information is “inaccessible” to the public and to those within the business who have no need of it.[2] Employers should consider providing employees with information on a need to know basis. While there is a useful and significant emphasis on teamwork and information sharing in business, this general trend should not be allowed to compromise the security of key information.

In each case, it must be demonstrated that reasonable efforts were made in the circumstances to maintain secrecy. The greater the effort to protect the information from disclosure, the more likely it will be that the courts will consider the information in question to be confidential.[3] Simply put, in any business context such as an arm's length negotiation or an employment relationship, limiting access to information will reduce the risk of dissemination. Of course, the degree to which protection is required will depend on the volume and nature of the information. The reality is that businesses will seek to maintain a level of secrecy equivalent to the value of their information.
Promotivate International Inc. v. Toronto Star Newspapers Ltd. (1985), 23 D.L.R. (4th) 196, 53 O.R. (2d) 9 (H.C.J.); Talbot v. General Television Corporation Pty. Ltd., [1981] R.P.C. 1 (S.C. Vict.).

R.L. Crain Ltd. v. Ashton, [1950] 1 D.L.R. 601, [1950] O.R. 62 (C.A.); Canada Bonded Attorney and Legal Directory Ltd. v. Leonard-Parmiter Ltd. (1918), 42 D.L.R. 342, 42 O.L.R. 141 (S.C.A.D.); Reliable Toy Co. v. Collins, [1950] 4 D.L.R. 499, [1950] O.R. 360 (H.C.).
Lansing Linde Ltd. v. Kerr, [1991] 1 All E.R. 418 (C.A.).
